ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: This course is really good. The department should offer more courses like this to help students get acquainted with certain research topics.

The course was a great exposure to a range of topics in causal inference. Due to the nature of the course as primarily lecture-based, and because some of the material was quite complex, students gained a familiarity with many of the topics, without necessarily having a deep understanding of all of them. An alternative approach for future, similar reading courses could be to have students responsible for presenting or discussing some part of the material; processing material in this way would force students to internalize it in a different way than absorbing readings and lectures does.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Forrest Crawford  Professor Crawford has a really wonderful facility for distilling complex topics to their core ideas, and presenting these in a clear, straightforward manner. In my experience this is very uncommon, and it greatly benefits his students.

Instructor: Peter Michael Aronow  Professor Aronow has a strong commitment to pedagogy--it appears he really wants his students to think clearly about causal inference. He has a great understanding of the material and a very clear perspective. He is not always open to competing perspectives, however. While I think he is usually right, it might benefit students to understand why, for example, certain methods continue to be used in spite of evident flaws.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: This course covered topics that would perhaps not be of interest to all students, but for those who would be interested in this material, I would easily recommend a similarly structured directed reading with Professors Crawford and Aronow.
